holidays.name: World Savings Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to promoting the importance of saving money and financial literacy worldwide, encouraging people to stash away a bit of their earnings for a rainy day.
holidays.origin: Started in 1924 by the International Savings Bank Congress to promote economic stability and personal financial responsibility.
holidays.funFact: Despite being on Halloween, many banks used to celebrate by giving out piggy banks instead of candy!

holidays.name: National Knock-Knock Jokes Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the groan-worthy and pun-filled classic knock-knock jokes that make you laugh, cringe, and question your sense of humor.
holidays.origin: An unofficial fun observance created by joke enthusiasts who appreciate this classic form of humor.
holidays.funFact: The first recorded knock-knock joke appeared in a 1936 edition of 'The Times,' making it a surprisingly modern joke format!

holidays.name: Caramel Apple Day
holidays.description: A sweet celebration honoring the delicious treat of apples dipped in sticky, buttery caramel—perfectly fitting for the Halloween season.
holidays.origin: Originated in the United States as an autumn favorite, popularized in the early 20th century as a seasonal candy apple variation.
holidays.funFact: Caramel apples were once considered a gourmet treat, with some recipes calling for caramel made from fresh cream and butter.

holidays.name: Mischief Night
holidays.description: The unofficial night before Halloween when pranks, mild vandalism, and general tomfoolery are traditionally tolerated in some regions.
holidays.origin: Tracing back to British traditions of ‘Devil’s Night’ or ‘Cabbage Night’—a time for harmless (and sometimes not so harmless) mischief before Halloween.
holidays.funFact: In some areas, Mischief Night antics led to local curfews because the ‘pranks’ got a little out of hand!
